questions.question: He plans to start his own business in ……………….. years.
questions.description: We can say ‘a few years’ or ‘a couple of’ years.

questions.question: Yesterday, I saw the movie that my friends ………………… the week before.
questions.description: We use the past perfect for the earlier of two past actions.

questions.question: She embarked …………. a career in law graduating from a prestigious law school.
We must guard ourselves …………… all possible infections.
We are doubtful ………………. winning the match.
The thief had been hiding in the warehouse ………………… morning.
questions.description: We use ‘since’ with the starting point. It is common after perfect tenses.

questions.question: Cars allow you to reach any place you want. ………………, they pose parking problems in cities.
questions.description: We use ‘however’ to suggest that what we are going to say contradicts what we have already said.

questions.question: John, as well as his cousins, …………… joining us.
questions.description: When we connect two subjects with ‘as well as’, the verb is likely to be singular if the first verb is singular.

questions.question: You had better hire a taxi. ……………… you will arrive late.
Tom ……………… ill last week.
questions.description:
The simple past is the normal tense for talking about finished actions in the past. 
The present perfect cannot be used with expressions that refer to a completely finished period of time.

questions.question: A grandparent’s job is easier than ………………..
questions.description: Either 'a parent's' or 'that of a parent' is possible here.

questions.question: It is important ………………….
questions.description: We put ‘not’ before infinitives and –ing forms.
